references: We present the experimental results for semantic correspondence in TableÂ 1. From the results, we have the following observations:

S6.T2.7.caption: Table 2:  Experimental results on semantic segmentation and its altered version with scarce labeled data, evaluated using mIoU â â \uparrow â  metric. The best results are in  bold  font and the runner-up is  underlined .
references:
As shown in the left part of TableÂ 2, Ours-XL-t and Ours-XL achieve state-of-the-art performance on the semantic segmentation task (45.71 and 43.45 v.s. 40.89 on ADE20K), demonstrating its effectiveness and generalizability.
Furthermore, the most competitive SOTA, Meta PromptsÂ [46], introduces a large number of trainable parameters and uses the diffusion U-Net recurrently, which is rather time-consuming.
In contrast, our method delivers superior results with efficiency maintained.

One advantage of diffusion features is the applicability to label-scarce scenariosÂ [2].
For validation under such conditions, we experiment on the label-scarce segmentation task, with results presented in the right part of TableÂ 2.
The observations are generally similar to those on the semantic correspondence task.
For example, Ours-v1.5 outperforms Legacy-v1.5 (60.2 v.s. 59.4),
Legacy-XL is inferior to Legacy-v1.5 (53.0 v.s. 59.4),
and Ours-XL is better than Ours-v1.5 (62.7 v.s. 60.2).

Implementation Details.
Both VPD and Meta Prompts perform full-scale fine-tuning on the diffusion U-Net using feedback from the discriminative task.
This heavy fine-tuning does not entirely comply with the motivation of diffusion feature, which seeks a balance between wider applicability and less training, and is hard to extend to the larger SDXL model.
Therefore, we keep the entire diffusion model frozen instead.
As the setting has been changed, the performance of VPD and Meta Prompts in TableÂ 2 is based on our experiments, not the reported results from the original papers.
Our implementation directly uses the hyper-parameters reported in Meta Prompts.

A4.T3.7.caption:
Table 3:  Examination of generalizability across different scenes.  Generic Solution  refers to our standard feature selection solution for SDXL, while  Specific Solution  refers to the outcome of considering only a simple scene for the quantitative comparison. The experiment is conducted on the label-scarce segmentation task, where the Horse-21 subset is used for simple scenes and the Bedroom-28 subset is used for complex scenes.
We mark the better results as  bold  font.
references:
As stated in SectionÂ 5, it is preferable to conduct the quantitative comparison across multiple datasets and choose activations that are optimal for each.
This approach can enhance the generalizability of the selected features.
To evaluate the generalizability of our features, we conducted an additional experiment, with results presented in TableÂ 3.

In this part, we present all the quantitative comparison results obtained following the protocol described in SectionÂ 5.
These results are from a dataset of simple scenes (Horse-21Â [2]) and a dataset of complex scenes (Bedroom-28Â [2]).
Since SDXL and Playground v2 share the same U-Net architecture, their results are shown in the same tables.
We display the results from the lowest resolution in TableÂ 4 and the results from the middle resolution in TableÂ 5.
We have also done a quantitative comparison on SDv1.5, and the results are shown in TableÂ 6.
